Description: Air Shunt Instruments Inc., a California aircraft components company, was sentenced to pay a criminal fine of $250,000 for false statements related to the illegal export of military technology.

A Dutch aviation services company was sentenced to five years of probation and a $100,000 fine after pleading guilty to federal charges related to a conspiracy to illegally export aircraft components and other items from the United States to entities in Iran via the Netherlands, the United Arab Emirates and Cyprus.

Balli Aviation Ltd., a subsidiary of the United Kingdom-based Balli Group PLC, was sentenced to pay a $2 million fine and to serve a five-year corporate period of probation after pleading guilty on Feb. 5, 2010, to a two-count criminal information in connection with its illegal export of commercial Boeing 747 aircraft from the United States to Iran.

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2014 Chiquita was purchased by Cutrale and Safra Group, each with a 50 percent share.
Description: Chiquita Brands International Inc. pleaded guilty to one count of engaging in transactions with a terrorist organization in Colombia.
Current Parent Ownership Structure: joint venture (owned 50-50 by Cutrale and Safra Group)

Description: GWC Valve International was sentenced to to a criminal fine of $300,000 and five years of corporate probation and ordered to forfeit $410,833.82 in connection after pleading guilty to charges of violating restrictions on the export of industrial valves to Iran.

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2011 ITT spun off its military businesses as Exelis Inc. In 2015 Exelis was acquired by Harris Corp., which in 2019 merged with L3 Technologies to form L3Harris Technologies.
Description: ITT Corporation, the leading manufacturer of military night vision equipment for the U.S. Armed Forces, admitted sending classified materials overseas and agreed to pay a $100 million criminal penalty, half of which was deferred.

ZTE Corporation agreed to enter a guilty plea and to pay a $430,488,798 penalty to the U.S. for conspiring to violate the International Emergency Economic Powers Act by illegally shipping U.S.-origin items to Iran, obstructing justice and making a material false statement. The plea agreement required that ZTE pay a fine in the amount of $286,992,532 and a criminal forfeiture in the amount of $143,496,266.

Recap of Ownership Changes: National Oilwell Varco changed its name to NOV in 2021

Description: United Microelectronics Corporation, Inc., a Taiwan semiconductor foundry, pleaded guilty to criminal trade secret theft and was sentenced to pay a $60 million fine, in exchange for its agreement to cooperate with the government in the investigation and prosecution of its co-defendant, a Chinese state-owned-enterprise.

A global supplier of cigarette paper products, PT Bukit Muria Jaya, agreed to pay a fine of $1,561,570 and enter into a deferred prosecution agreement with the Justice Department for conspiring to commit bank fraud in connection with the shipment of products to North Korean customers.

SAP acknowledged violations of the Export Administration Regulations and the Iranian Transactions and Sanctions Regulations. As a result of its voluntary disclosure to DOJ, extensive cooperation and strong remediation costing more than $27 million, DOJ's National Security Division (NSD) and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Massachusetts entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with SAP. Pursuant to that agreement, SAP agreed to disgorge $5.14 million of ill-gotten gain.

Avnet Asia Pte. Ltd. agreed to pay $1,508,000 and enter into a non-prosecution agreement after admitting responsibility for an employee's unlawful conspiracy to ship export-controlled U.S. goods with potential military applications to China, and also for the criminal conduct of another former employee who, from 2007-2009, illegally caused U.S. goods to be shipped to China and Iran without a license.

British American Tobacco (BAT) and its subsidiary, BAT Marketing Singapore (BATMS), one of the world's largest manufacturers of tobacco products, agreed to pay combined penalties of more than $629 million to resolve bank fraud and sanctions violations charges with U.S. authorities, arising out of the companies' scheme to do business in North Korea through a third-party company in Singapore, in violation of the bank fraud statute and the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA).  BATMS pleaded guilty to a criminal information filed in the District of Columbia charging BAT and BATMS with conspiracy to commit bank fraud and conspiracy to violate IEEPA. BAT entered into a deferred prosecution agreement (DPA) related to the same charges.

Taiwan business organization DES International Co. Ltd. (DES), and Brunei business organization Soltech Industry Co. Ltd. (Soltech) each pleaded guilty to conspiring to defraud the United States and to violate the International Emergency Economic Powers Act and the Iranian Transactions and Sanctions Regulations. The two companies were each sentenced to pay a fine of $83,769, which is three times the value of the goods unlawfully exported to Iran, and to serve a five-year term of corporate probation.

Taiwan business organization DES International Co. Ltd. (DES), and Brunei business organization Soltech Industry Co. Ltd. (Soltech) each pleaded guilty to conspiring to defraud the United States and to violate the International Emergency Economic Powers Act and the Iranian Transactions and Sanctions Regulations. The two companies were each sentenced to pay a fine of $83,769, which is three times the value of the goods unlawfully exported to Iran, and to serve a five-year term of corporate probation.

Suez Rajan Limited pleaded guilty to conspiring to violate the International Emergency Economic Powers Act through its involvement in the shipment of Iranian crude oil. The company was sentenced to three years of corporate probation and a fine of almost $2.5 million.

Binance Holdings Limited, the entity that operates the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, Binance.com, pleaded guilty and agreed to pay over $4 billion to resolve the Justice Department's investigation into violations related to the Bank Secrecy Act (BSA), failure to register as a money transmitting business, and the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). As part of the plea agreement, Binance agreed to forfeit $2,510,650,588 and to pay a criminal fine of $1,805,475,575 for a total financial penalty of $4,316,126,163. Binance also agreed to retain an independent compliance monitor for three years and remediate and enhance their anti-money laundering and sanctions compliance programs.
